content:
âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Statement is clear & difficulty level is justified by the big numbers test/validator not passing with the naive implementation.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very nice puzzle which is in fact made up of two sub-problems. Need some trick to pass all the tests and validators. So i think the medium category is a good choice.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Cool idea ðŸ’¡

I would adjust two test cases, also:

- "Big numbers" test is a bit easier to pass than Validator 2, due to smaller numbers; if my code barely passes the test, it could fail the validator. I would change the validator to be the same or easier difficulty compared to its test.

- "Will it fit?" has some factors, but the Validator does not; maybe there's a chance someone's code fails when wallpaper is blank? Just in case, I would add some factors to Validator 4. If you want to cover the empty paper too, I would add an extra test just for that.

That's a cool idea for this puzzle.
To me it wasn't clear I need to stop at first consecutive number that doesn't fit, then fill rest with dashes. Also, would be cool to look for wording optimizations if you get the time - e.g. 
- "wants to have a wallpaper" > "wants a wallpaper"
- "on a sheet of wallpaper given the size of ..." > "on a wallpaper of fixed width and height"
- "by a single comma" > "by a comma"
Also some typos I noticed:
- "[...] consecutive numbers and its prime factors" > "and their prime factors"
- "numbers fit on a single they" > missing "row" + comma

Good luck getting it published!

Output section and Cases
* The output section is too long. You may move all of it except the first line to Goal section.

* You may remove the "," and "and" in between the first three examples. A bullet list may be sufficient for readability.

* You may also remove the full example within there, and instead, add it as a Test of the first pair of cases and add another validator to that pair. The first pair of cases should be simple, so the suggested change will achieve that as well.

Stub generator
* You may need to treat [[number]] as a long instead of an int?

Thanks.

Moved the description, did some cleanup. Removed the example, the first testcase is already sufficiently simple enough. The reason I added the example was so you can see a few lines all at once but agree with you that that is not ness. here. 

I could not find the exact defenition of int and long. number should always be smaller than 2**31 so I think int should suffice.
Thanks for the better wording. Applied them and added some clarifications about the line endings
Agreed. I swapped the big numbers <-> validator 2 and created a new testcase Impossible

Looking better already.
I would also add mention that you stop at first number that doesn't fit on a line; e.g. in "Will it fit?" test 96 doesn't fit anymore, but what prevents me from continuing at 97? Maybe it's already obvious because of "consecutive", but I would define it clearly.
And some grammar and wording:
- still have to fix the typos above
- "added to the wallpaper consecutive" > "consecutively"
- "5 won't fix" > "5 doesn't fit"
Don't forget you can always use Grammarly or some other tool to check language, punctuation, wording and the like.

On another topic, I just noticed the sieve algo in the proposed solution. That's actually pretty cool (and probably a lot more efficient than my initial code). Good job!

You're a great help, thanks. I deliberately named the puzzle "Eratosthenes' wallpaper" because he thought of this sieve already in ancient times. Just a nudge to how to make an efficient solution :-).

Cool!
There is still a missing "row, " in "if numbers don't fit in a single they ...". Don't forget it, ok?
Otherwise, looks good to me!
